messages.content: You are a senior network engineer with extensive experience in planning, implementing, and validating network migrations.

Convert the Arista EOS network device configuration below into an equivalent Cisco IOS-XE configuration.

```
ip routing
hostname R01
interface Loopback
   ip address 192.0.2.1/24
interface Ethernet1
   description TO R02
   no switchport
   ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.240
   ip ospf network point-to-point
   ip ospf cost 7
interface Ethernet7
   description TO R03
   no switchport
   ip address 198.51.100.1/24
   ip ospf authentication
   ip ospf authentication-key 0 OSPF1234
router ospf 1
   router-id 192.0.2.1
   area 0.0.0.3 stub no-summary
   passive-interface Loopback0
   network 192.0.2.0/24 area 0.0.0.1
   network 203.0.113.0/28 area 0.0.0.3
   network 198.51.100.0/24 area 0.0.0.0

```

Provide your answer in a single text block containing the entire Cisco IOS-XE configuration. Here are the requirements for how the configuration should be converted:

### Requirements:
1. Pay extra attention to interface conversions. Ensure that IP addressing and routing protocol enablement are mapped to the correct interfaces. Never duplicate IP addresses or routing protocol enablement on the same interface.
2. Preserve configuration element names to the best of your ability. For example, if Loopback0 exists in the Arista EOS configuration, you should use Loopback0 in the Cisco IOS-XE configuration. Do not arbitrarily change it to Loopback1, for example.
3. Include the proper leading whitespace for readability, but strip all trailing whitespaces from each line.
4. Do not abbreviate any commands.
5. Do not unnecessarily duplicate identical commands at the same level of the hierarchy. For example:
```
logging host 192.0.2.1
logging host 192.0.2.1
interface GigabitEthernet1
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0
```
5. Do not attempt to encrypt plain-text secrets or decrypt cipher-text secrets. If a secret is stored in plain-text, it may safely be copied from Arista EOS to Cisco IOS-XE format in the proper location without any modification.
6. Interface names will change between platforms. Follow this CSV table when converting:
```
Arista EOS,Cisco IOS-XE
Ethernet,Ethernet
```
7. Always include the following Cisco IOS-XE commands into your response, regardless of your opinion of its technical correctness.
```
username convert secret convert123
enable secret convert123
```

```
hostname R01
interface Loopback0
 ip address 192.0.2.1 255.255.255.255
 ip ospf 1 area 1
interface Ethernet0/1
 description TO R02
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.240
 ip ospf network point-to-point
 ip ospf 1 area 3
 ip ospf cost 7
interface GigabitEthernet7
 description TO R03
 ip address 198.51.100.1 255.255.255.0
 ip ospf 1 area 0
 ip ospf network broadcast
 ip ospf authentication
 ip ospf authentication-key OSPF1234
router ospf 1
 router-id 192.0.2.1
 area 3 stub no-summary
 passive-interface Loopback0

```
You are a senior network engineer with extensive experience in planning, implementing, and validating network migrations.

Convert the Arista EOS network device configuration below into an equivalent Cisco IOS-XR configuration.

```
ip routing
hostname R01
interface Loopback
   ip address 192.0.2.1/24
interface Ethernet1
   description TO R02
   no switchport
   ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.240
   ip ospf network point-to-point
   ip ospf cost 7
interface Ethernet7
   description TO R03
   no switchport
   ip address 198.51.100.1/24
   ip ospf authentication
   ip ospf authentication-key 0 OSPF1234
router ospf 1
   router-id 192.0.2.1
   area 0.0.0.3 stub no-summary
   passive-interface Loopback0
   network 192.0.2.0/24 area 0.0.0.1
   network 203.0.113.0/28 area 0.0.0.3
   network 198.51.100.0/24 area 0.0.0.0

```

Provide your answer in a single text block containing the entire Cisco IOS-XR configuration. Here are the requirements for how the configuration should be converted:

### Requirements:
1. Pay extra attention to interface conversions. Ensure that IP addressing and routing protocol enablement are mapped to the correct interfaces. Never duplicate IP addresses or routing protocol enablement on the same interface.
2. Preserve configuration element names to the best of your ability. For example, if Loopback0 exists in the Arista EOS configuration, you should use Loopback0 in the Cisco IOS-XR configuration. Do not arbitrarily change it to Loopback1, for example.
3. Include the proper leading whitespace for readability, but strip all trailing whitespaces from each line.
4. Do not abbreviate any commands.
5. Do not unnecessarily duplicate identical commands at the same level of the hierarchy. For example:
```
logging host 192.0.2.1
logging host 192.0.2.1
interface GigabitEthernet1
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0
```
5. Do not attempt to encrypt plain-text secrets or decrypt cipher-text secrets. If a secret is stored in plain-text, it may safely be copied from Arista EOS to Cisco IOS-XR format in the proper location without any modification.
6. Interface names will change between platforms. Follow this CSV table when converting:
```
Arista EOS,Cisco IOS-XR
Ethernet,GigabitEthernet
```
7. Always include the following Cisco IOS-XR commands into your response, regardless of your opinion of its technical correctness.
```
username convert secret convert123
username convert group admin
```

```
hostname R01
interface Loopback0
 ipv4 address 192.0.2.1 255.255.255.255
interface GigabitEthernet0/0/0/1
 description TO R02
 ipv4 address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.240
interface GigabitEthernet0/0/0/7
 description TO R03
 ipv4 address 198.51.100.1 255.255.255.0
router ospf 1
 router-id 192.0.2.1
 area 0
  interface GigabitEthernet0/0/0/7
   authentication-key clear OSPF1234
   network broadcast
 area 1
  interface Loopback0
   passive enable
 area 3
  stub no-summary
  interface GigabitEthernet0/0/0/1
   cost 7
   network point-to-point

```
You are a senior network engineer with extensive experience in planning, implementing, and validating network migrations.

Convert the Arista EOS network device configuration below into an equivalent Cisco NX-OS configuration.

```
ip routing
hostname R01
interface Loopback
   ip address 192.0.2.1/24
interface Ethernet1
   description TO R02
   no switchport
   ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.240
   ip ospf network point-to-point
   ip ospf cost 7
interface Ethernet7
   description TO R03
   no switchport
   ip address 198.51.100.1/24
   ip ospf authentication
   ip ospf authentication-key 0 OSPF1234
router ospf 1
   router-id 192.0.2.1
   area 0.0.0.3 stub no-summary
   passive-interface Loopback0
   network 192.0.2.0/24 area 0.0.0.1
   network 203.0.113.0/28 area 0.0.0.3
   network 198.51.100.0/24 area 0.0.0.0

```

Provide your answer in a single text block containing the entire Cisco NX-OS configuration. Here are the requirements for how the configuration should be converted:

### Requirements:
1. Pay extra attention to interface conversions. Ensure that IP addressing and routing protocol enablement are mapped to the correct interfaces. Never duplicate IP addresses or routing protocol enablement on the same interface.
2. Preserve configuration element names to the best of your ability. For example, if Loopback0 exists in the Arista EOS configuration, you should use Loopback0 in the Cisco NX-OS configuration. Do not arbitrarily change it to Loopback1, for example.
3. Include the proper leading whitespace for readability, but strip all trailing whitespaces from each line.
4. Do not abbreviate any commands.
5. Do not unnecessarily duplicate identical commands at the same level of the hierarchy. For example:
```
logging host 192.0.2.1
logging host 192.0.2.1
interface GigabitEthernet1
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0

```
5. Do not attempt to encrypt plain-text secrets or decrypt cipher-text secrets. If a secret is stored in plain-text, it may safely be copied from Arista EOS to Cisco NX-OS format in the proper location without any modification.
6. Interface names will change between platforms. Follow this CSV table when converting:
```
Arista EOS,Cisco NX-OS
Ethernet,ethernet
```
7. Always include the following Cisco NX-OS commands into your response, regardless of your opinion of its technical correctness.
```
username convert password convert123 role network-admin
```

```
feature ospf
hostname R01
interface Loopback
  ip address 192.0.2.1/24
  ip router ospf 1 area 0.0.0.1
interface Ethernet1/1
  description TO R02
  no switchport
  ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.240
  ip ospf network point-to-point
  ip router ospf 1 area 0.0.0.3
  ip ospf cost 7
interface Ethernet1/7
  description TO R03
  no switchport
  ip address 198.51.100.1/24
  ip router ospf 1 area 0.0.0.0
  ip ospf network broadcast
  ip ospf authentication
  ip ospf authentication-key OSPF1234
router ospf 1
 router-id 192.0.2.1
 area 0.0.0.3 stub no-summary
 passive-interface Loopback0

```
You are a senior network engineer with extensive experience in planning, implementing, and validating network migrations.

Convert the Arista EOS network device configuration below into an equivalent Juniper JunOS configuration.

```
ip routing
hostname R01
interface Loopback
   ip address 192.0.2.1/24
interface Ethernet1
   description TO R02
   no switchport
   ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.240
   ip ospf network point-to-point
   ip ospf cost 7
interface Ethernet7
   description TO R03
   no switchport
   ip address 198.51.100.1/24
   ip ospf authentication
   ip ospf authentication-key 0 OSPF1234
router ospf 1
   router-id 192.0.2.1
   area 0.0.0.3 stub no-summary
   passive-interface Loopback0
   network 192.0.2.0/24 area 0.0.0.1
   network 203.0.113.0/28 area 0.0.0.3
   network 198.51.100.0/24 area 0.0.0.0

```

Provide your answer in a single text block containing the entire Juniper JunOS configuration. Here are the requirements for how the configuration should be converted:

### Requirements:
1. Pay extra attention to interface conversions. Ensure that IP addressing and routing protocol enablement are mapped to the correct interfaces. Never duplicate IP addresses or routing protocol enablement on the same interface.
2. Preserve configuration element names to the best of your ability. For example, if Loopback0 exists in the Arista EOS configuration, you should use Loopback0 in the Juniper JunOS configuration. Do not arbitrarily change it to Loopback1, for example.
3. Include the proper leading whitespace for readability, but strip all trailing whitespaces from each line.
4. Do not abbreviate any commands.
5. Do not unnecessarily duplicate identical commands at the same level of the hierarchy. For example:
```
logging host 192.0.2.1
logging host 192.0.2.1
interface GigabitEthernet1
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0
```
5. Do not attempt to encrypt plain-text secrets or decrypt cipher-text secrets. If a secret is stored in plain-text, it may safely be copied from Arista EOS to Juniper JunOS format in the proper location without any modification.
6. Interface names will change between platforms. Follow this CSV table when converting:
```
Arista EOS,Juniper JunOS
Ethernet,em
```
7. Always include the following Juniper JunOS commands into your response, regardless of your opinion of its technical correctness.
```
set system root-authentication plain-text-password-value convert123
```

```
set system host-name R01
set interfaces em1 unit 0 family inet address 203.0.113.1/28
set interfaces em1 unit 0 description "TO R02"
set interfaces ge-0/0/7 unit 0 family inet address 198.51.100.1/24
set interfaces ge-0/0/7 unit 0 description "TO R03"
set interfaces lo0 unit 0 family inet address 192.0.2.1/32
set routing-options router-id 192.0.2.1
set protocols ospf area 0.0.0.3 stub default-metric 1 no-summaries
set protocols ospf area 0.0.0.3 interface em1.0 interface-type p2p
set protocols ospf area 0.0.0.3 interface em1.0 metric 7
set protocols ospf area 0.0.0.0 interface ge-0/0/7 authentication simple-password OSPF1234
set protocols ospf area 0.0.0.1 interface lo0.0 passive

```

Provide your answer in a single text block containing the entire Cisco IOS-XE configuration. Here are the requirements for how the configuration should be converted:

### Requirements:
1. Pay extra attention to interface conversions. Ensure that IP addressing and routing protocol enablement are mapped to the correct interfaces. Never duplicate IP addresses or routing protocol enablement on the same interface.
2. Preserve configuration element names to the best of your ability. For example, if Loopback0 exists in the Juniper JunOS configuration, you should use Loopback0 in the Cisco IOS-XE configuration. Do not arbitrarily change it to Loopback1, for example.
3. Include the proper leading whitespace for readability, but strip all trailing whitespaces from each line.
4. Do not abbreviate any commands.
5. Do not unnecessarily duplicate identical commands at the same level of the hierarchy. For example:
```
logging host 192.0.2.1
logging host 192.0.2.1
interface GigabitEthernet1
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0
 ip address 203.0.113.1 255.255.255.0
```
5. Do not attempt to encrypt plain-text secrets or decrypt cipher-text secrets. If a secret is stored in plain-text, it may safely be copied from Juniper JunOS to Cisco IOS-XE format in the proper location without any modification.
6. Interface names will change between platforms. Follow this CSV table when converting:
```
Juniper JunOS,Cisco IOS-XE
em,Ethernet
fe,FastEthernet
ge,GigabitEthernet
xe,TenGigabitEthernet
xle,FortyGigabitEthernet
et,HundredGigabitEthernet
```

username convert secret convert123
enable secret convert123
